text:
Problem Overview

Students revisit a setting from the How Likely Is It? unit. They choose colored blocks from a bag to use random samples to estimate population. They analyze student strategies for using the sample to determine the population. The students will then look at a data set of a mystery container to determine the number of blue cubes in the container.

Arc of Learning

Reasoning About Samples and Populations: Introduction, Exploration

Proportional Relationships: Analysis

NWDYK

How can we use random sampling to estimate populations?

Emerging Mathematical Ideas

Students investigate using random samples.

They will:

  • conduct an experiment that takes several samples of the same size to determine a population
  • use line plots of samples to describe an entire population
  • use proportional reasoning and scaling up samples to determine an entire population
  • use median of samples to predict the total population
  • analyze sample data given in box and whisker plot and line plot to generalize characteristics of a population

Launch (Getting Started)

Connecting to Prior Knowledge

You may want to connect back to the unit Data About Us to make sure students know what a remember the measures of center – median and mean.

Suggested Questions:

  • Imagine that I have a set of data that has 5 observations and the median is 6. What does mean? (You have 5 data values. If you put the data values in order, the middle value would be 6.)
  • What might a line plot of that data look like? (Many possibilities. There would be five quantities in order from smallest to largest. The middle value would be 6. The first two values can be any number from 0 to 6. The last two values can be any number ≥ 6. See a couple of possible data sets below.)

If needed, you can also revisit the mean.

Suggested Questions:

  • Would the mean of the data distributions be the same as the median? (Usually it is a different value. With mean, we distribute the quantities. It is like each data observation shares and balances out their values with the other data observations.)
  • How do we find the mean? (Add up the data values and divide by how many values that we have.)
  • What are the means for the data sets that we just created? (Answers will vary based on your data sets.)

For the examples above,

Presenting the Challenge

Connect to the unit How Likely Is It? by reviewing the Gee Whiz Everyone Wins Game.

Suggested Questions:

  • What did we do when we played the game? (Answers will vary. The class drew cubes and recorded the colors chosen to find the experimental probability of a red cube being chosen.)
  • After finding the experimental probability, how did we find the theoretical probability of a red cube being chosen? (# red cubes)/(total number of cubes)

Show students the 100 blocks in the container. Mix them up.

Suggested Question:

  • If we select a random sample of blocks from the container, will the sample have the same proportions of colored cubes as the whole population? (Answers will vary. Have students record their prediction.)

Implementation Note: If you had students collect their samples during Problem 1.1 Explore have them pull that out to use. If you didn’t do that they will have to collect data first. Have one large bucket with the 50 red, 20 yellow, and 30 green cubes. Carry out the random sample as a whole group. Then have groups of 4 students take turns getting their data. A sample size is 10 and they repeat the sampling ten times. Students will use their data as the proceed through the problem. (Problem Solving Environment)

If you don’t have cubes you can use Teaching Aid 1.2: 100 Chart with Cube Colors to represent the cubes.
